entry.title: Injection
entry.summary: Overview of the selection process for brine injection project
entry.content:
Brine injection is selected as the basis for a "quick and dirty" project where an adaptive method will help achieve a more optimal addition of salt to meat products. The project's duration is confined to 3-4 month, this means that it is necessary to clearly deliminate the problem and make wide use of "hand held" solutions in order to reduce setup time and quickly test the adaptive method.

Process description

Brine is added to a wide range of meats before packaging in order to mature and tenderize the meat as well as enhance flavor. The brine consists of water and a mix of salt, phosphate, nitrate, sugar or flavoring. The central ingredient is the salt, which has the effect of increases the solubility of proteins and thereby improve the meats ability to retain water. However, if the salt concentration gets too high, the effect is reversed and the muscle fibers shrink and proteins risk getting washed out. For the best results, the brine should be uniformly distributed thorughout the meat. This can be achieved by administering the brine externally or by injecting it directly into the meat. The salt will then diffuse through the meat and distribute evenly, with time, through chemical processes. Salt is able to diffuse at the most 0.5 cm. per day, so if the brine needs to defuse over long distances, it becomes very time intensive and impractical for modern industrial processes. The standard practice for quickly curing meat is injection of brine using a grid of needles. When using current injection systems alone, the results are not always satisfactory and the meat is subjected to additional treatments both before and after the injection of brine. The meat's ability to absorb the brine can be improved by hammering before injection, this extends the muscle fibers, which increase room for brine and improves the distribution. Similarly, the diffusion of the injected brine along with additional absorbition can be achieved by post-injection mechanical treatment. [TODO] Write more about the post-injection treatment.

A rapport "Accelereret saltning med multistiksprøjtning" [2] from the running DMRI project, "Optimeret produktion af forædlede kødprodukter" investigates the possibilities for reducing the time needed to salt pructs using existing equipment. The process can be helped along by treating the meat mechanically. Advanced machinery exisits for both injection and mechanical treatment, but no single manufactura provides a complete state-of-the-art solution and slaughterhouses largely rely on older outdated machinery. The goal of that part of the project is to reduce the process to under one day(7 hours).

The process can be be very complex when the natural variation and the many physical and chemical variables are taken into account. The main physical variables are: - Injection pattern * The denseness of the injection * The strategy for injecting brine, e.g. continously, when stationary, multiple times - Meat texture * The xxx - State of muscle fibers * The degree to which the fibers are prepared to absorbe the brine - Brine injection pressure - Injection speed/time - Pressure at the point of injection * Depend on the flow through the other holes in the needle(s) * Holes maybe be blocked

Some of the most important chemical variables are:

  • Salt concentration
    • Water retention increases with the concentration of salt
    • Very high salt concentrations reverses the effect
  • Type of salt
    • NaCl is significantly better than KCl at improving water retention
  • Sugar concentration
    • Sugar has a similar effect to salt
  • Phosphate concentration
    • Phosphate increases the pH and water retention
  • pH
    • pH decides which ion, Na+ or Cl-, plays the primary role in increasing water retention
    • A pH value around 6 has shown to lead to optimal water retention for NaCl
  • Temperature
    • Low temperature contributes to better water retention, 4° being optimal
    • High temperature speeds up the diffusion of salt through the meat
  • Type of meat
    • the amount of protein and the ratios between protein types, e.g. intracellular(soluble) and extracellular(non-soluble), differs between cuts
    • The pH differs between cuts, e.g. pork shoulder has a much higher pH than loin

Initial experiment

An initial experiment was conducted in order to investigate the effect of the two primary process parameters; brine pressure and injection speed, as well as determine the possibilities for visually measuring the gain using 3D sensing. The details of the experiment are described in multistiksprøjte eksperiment.

State-of-the-art

Meat preparation

Some of the leading products for mechanical preparation of meat before injection of brine are:

STEAKER/PRESSES by Günther (DE)

MACMAX by Schröder (DE):

TwinHammer 5500 by METALQUIMIA

Pre-massaging unit that stretch the muscle fibers, which increase the space around fibrils. Leads to a reduction in the time needed for tumbling after injection. twinhammer

Bladehammer 5500 by METALQUIMIA

bladehammer

Brine injection

In the meat industry, brine is most commonly added using machines with multiple injection needles, the number of needles typically ranges from 40 to 500 with a spacing of 12-25 mm. Correct adjustment of the injector has a large impact on the time needed for the salt to properly diffuse. [3]

New needles that are thinner and have more holes

SPRAY PLUS High pressure Too much pressure?

IMAX 420 by Schröder (DE):

Integrated weights that automatically controls and adapts the injection speed during operation.

Many and very thin needles as well as independent control of conveyorbelt, which allows for a very dense injection pattern

Individual needle damage and flow detection.

IMAX 420

PI 750 DUO by Günther (DE)

Spray Plus Traditionally, brine is injected using needles with a few holes that has a diameter above 1 mm and a low brine pressure of a few bars. With the spray plus system, Günther introduces a spray system where the needles have many holes with a small diameter and a very high brine pressure. This reuslts in very fine droplets that should distribute well in the meat. Because of the much improved distribution of brine, the drip loss is reduced significantly.

The classical low presure injection technique:

(1) Brine injection from the start, (2) Spraying continous as the needles descend

(3) Needles reach the bottom and leaves pockets of brine, (4) As the needles are withdrawn, brine collects in the holes

(5) As the needles leave the meat, brine will escape

The new high pressure injection technique:

(1) Needles enters the meat without spraying brine, (2) needles continoue al the way to the bottom without spraying

\ (3) Brine is spayed using high pressure from all holes, (4) Needles are withdrawn without spraying brine

The efficacy of the technology has not been verified independently yet

PI 750 DUO

M3 byFOMACO (DK)

Inline Weight Controller (IWC) constantly monitors the injection quantity and corrects the settings in case of irregularities.

M3

Movistick Plus 5500 by METALQUIMIA

Movistick Plus 5500

MOVIPLUS 4.0 by METALQUIMIA

MOVIPLUS 4.0 Up & Down system for regulating the depth the needles will penetrate in order to avoid injecting fat and skin

Other manufacturas include GAROS (SE), Marel (IS)

Tumbling

The diffusion of salt is helped along by the use of mechanical tumbling, which quickly can distribute the salt up to 2 cm. [3] The meat is gently tumbled, resulting in a massage of the meat that helps drain unabsorbed brine and thereby avoiding pockets of brine as well as closing up the holes that are left from the injection.

DRYBINDER by METALQUIMIA (ES)

DRIPPING TUNNEL by Metalbud Nowicki (PL)

Possible improvements

Here is a list of features that has the potential to improve speed, quality and knowledge of the product in general. Some of the features already exist in available machines.

  • Speed
    • Increased injection cadence
  • Quality
    • Adjustable injection depth
    • Flow monitoring
    • Finer injection patterns without needing more and tighter packed needles
    • Advanced injection patterns
    • Avoiding areas with bone or non muscle tissue
    • Avoid local extreeme concentrations of salt
  • Knowledge

To text: - Injection into meat that contain bones, areas of fat or cartilage * Meat that contain bones will break needles and pockets of brine can form around the bone * Areas with concentrations of fat or other non-meat tissues should not be injected with brine - Achieving a uniform distribution of brine quickly * Multiple process steps and a lot of time is required to insure a satisfactory result * Individual and local differences in meat's abilities to absorb the brine are not taken into account

Measuring quality of injection

In order to do optimization a method for determining the quality of the salting is necessary.

  • CT scanning, use contrast fluid if necessary
  • Slice and photograph, use contrast fluid if necessary
  • Injection of salt-meter electrodes to sample salinity
  • Local increase in weight/volume
  • Drip loss/non-absorbed brine
  • (Uniform external color change)
  • (Firmness of meat)

Measuring salt content: Salt in brine and Salt in meat

Project possibilities

  • Process optimization

    • Optimal preparation of meat for uniform salt distribution
      • Hammer/massage meat
    • Optimal injection for uniform salt distribution
      • Optimal injection compared to fiber orientation
    • Optimal post injection processing

  • Controlling process parameters

Ideas: - For each type of meat run experiments to explore the parameter space to find optimal control parameters * Simple investigation of the individual parameters or gridsearch for also investigating interactions * Classifier learns the correlation and predicts result

  • Use ML to predict the optimal process parameters for the individual pieces of meat or even the local area of the meat
    • Is it possible to find features that allow us to distiguish meats?

(Learning to learn by gradient descent by gradient descent)[https://arxiv.org/abs/1606.04474]

  • Estimating volume/weight from 2D or 3D images

Project directions

Basic "chip-tuning" focused on existing medium-low tier machines * Automation of process parameters using feedback from weighing before and after injection

  • Advanced "chip-tuning" focused on existing top tier machines
    • Automatic switching between recipes based on detection of meat type
    • Local adjustment of brine based on

  • Robot cell for experimentation, specifically determining local absorption properties
    • Local injection of brine followed by weighing in order to determine local gain
  • Robot cell solution
    • Highly customized injection patterns
    • High flexibility in application
    • Automatic cleaning

  • Misc. additions
    • Monitoring of flow and detection of blocked needles
    • Avoiding brine injection into non-muscle areas e.g. fat and air pockets. Requires CT scanning or similar.
    • Robotic pre-massaging of meat in order to improve
